case.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: an example of a particular situation or of something happening
case.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Tom’s career is a case in point (=a clear example of something that you are discussing or explaining).
a classic case (=typical example) of poor design
There were 16 cases of damage to cars in the area.
The amount of fruit in fruit juices must be 6% in the case of berries and 10% in the case of other fruits.
In many cases standards have improved.
case.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a situation that exists, especially as it affects a particular person or group
case.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Like the others, he produced a written explanation, but in Scott’s case this was a 30-page printed booklet.
Changing men’s and women’s traditional roles is not easy, but in our case it has been helpful.
It may be the case that the scheme will need more money.
We tend to think of these people as untrustworthy, but that is not the case.
In this case, several solutions could be tried.
He won’t want to eat it unless he’s really hungry, in which case he’ll eat almost anything.
case.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a set of reasons why something should happen or be done
case.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Let me research the facts before I put forward a case.
A group of us met to make our case for more women in the cabinet.
There is a strong case (=very good set of reasons) for getting parents more involved in the school’s activities.
case.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a question or problem that will be dealt with by a law court
case.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: She is keen to avoid a court case.
The lawyers will only be paid if they win the case.
Marshall has dropped the case against us.
case.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: all the reasons that one side in a legal argument can give against the other side
case.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The evidence does not support the prosecution’s case.
The court ruled that we had a case (=had enough evidence or good arguments).
case.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: an event or set of events that need to be dealt with by the police in order to find out if a crime has been committed and who committed it
case.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Around 50 police officers are on the case.
case.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: a large box or container in which things can be stored or moved
case.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a special box used as a container for holding or protecting something
case.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Jim put his violin back in its case.
case.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Polly carried her cases upstairs to the bedroom.
case.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: an example of a disease or a person who has a disease
case.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: There are thousands of new cases of AIDS in Africa every year.
case.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: the way in which the form of a word changes, showing its relationship to other words in a sentence
case.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: someone who is being dealt with by a doctor, a social worker, the police etc
case.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 7a:
case.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + case
a court case
There was a lot of publicity surrounding the court case.
a murder case
He had been a witness in a murder case.
a libel case
damages awarded by juries in libel cases
a criminal case
It was the longest and most expensive criminal case in US history.
a civil case
He is involved with civil cases, not criminal ones.
a test case
If the dispute goes to court it could be an important test case.
a landmark case
a landmark case about copyright protection for computer software
a high-profile case
a defense lawyer who has handled some high-profile cases
bring a case (against somebody)
There was not enough evidence to bring a case against him.
hear/try a case
The case will be heard by a federal judge.
win/lose a case
Lomax was a brilliant lawyer who had never lost a case.
settle a case
He paid a $15,000 fine to settle the case.
adjourn a case
The case was adjourned until next month for further reports.
dismiss/throw out a case
The case was thrown out by New York state’s highest court.
drop a case
The case was dropped because of a lack of evidence.
a case comes/goes to court
When the case finally came to court, they were found not guilty.
a case comes/goes to trial
By the time her case went to trial, her story had changed.
a case comes before a judge/court
The case came before the federal courts.
case.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a large box or container in which things can be stored or moved
case.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: a case of 10,000 cigarettes and several cases of spirits
case.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a question or problem that will be dealt with by a court of law
case.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: those claiming damages in personal injury cases
The Council appealed to them to drop the case (=stop investigating it).
case.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: all the reasons that one side in a legal argument can give against the other side
case.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The prosecution case was that the victim was stabbed by Reid during a general disturbance.
The plaintiff needed legal representation in order to present her case properly.
